title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Run colSums(random_vars) / 1000 to obtain \(E[\text{age}] = 33.471\) and \(E[\text{income}] = 3510.731\)
Run var(random_vars[1]) and var(random_vars[2]) to obtain \(Var[age] = 340.6078\) and \(Var[income] = 8625646\)
Take the square roots of the variances to obtain \(\sigma_{age} = 18.456\) and \(\sigma_{income} = 2936.945\)

title: Probability Theory
text:
1 Assignment I
\[\begin{gather}
P(T \cap S) =  0.2 * 0.3 = 0.06 \\
P(T \cap \overline{S}) =  0.6 * 0.7 = 0.42 \\
P(\overline{T} \cap S) =  0.8 * 0.3 = 0.24 \\
P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) =  0.4 * 0.7 = 0.28 \\
P(T \cap S) + P(T \cap \overline{S}) + P(\overline{T} \cap S) + P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = 1
\end{gather}\]


2 Assignment II

Percentage of customers using all three devices:

0.5%

Percentage of customers using at least 2 devices:

\(7.3 + 3.3 + 8.8 + 0.5 = 19.9\text{%}\)

Percentage of customers using only one device:

\(27.8 + 42.3 + 10.0 = 80.1\text{%}\)




3 Assignment III
From the given info we have \(P(B|A) = 0.97\) and \(P(B|\overline{A}) = 0.01\)
and thus: \(P(\overline{B}|\overline{A}) = 0.99\)
\(P(B) = P(B|A) * P(A) + P(B|\overline{A}) * P(\overline{A}) = 0.97 * 0.04 + 0.01 * 0.96 = 0.0484\)
\(P( \overline{A}|B ) = \frac{P(B|\overline{A}) P(\overline{A})} {P(B)} = \frac{0.01 * 0.96}{0.0484} = 0.1983\)
\(P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) P(A)}{P(B)} = \frac{0.97 * 0.04}{0.0484} = 0.8017\)
These probabilities add up to 1, as they should

Run colSums(random_vars) / 1000 to obtain \(E[\text{age}] = 33.471\) and \(E[\text{income}] = 3510.731\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text: 2 d

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Run colSums(random_vars) / 1000 to obtain \(E(\text{age}) = 33.471\) and \(E(\text{income}) = 3510.731\)
Run var(random_vars[1]) and var(random_vars[2]) to obtain \(Var(age) = 340.6078\) and \(Var(income) = 8625646\)
Take the square roots of the variances to obtain \(\sigma_{age} = 18.456\) and \(\sigma_{income} = 2936.945\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
2 Problem 2
It does not make sense to compare the standard deviations alone, since the numbers are different orders of magnitude. That is, a difference in age by 50 is a significant, but a difference in income by 50 is not. One could scale the standard deviation in some way with respect to the expected value for a better comparison.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
3 Problem 3

Running cov(random_vars) shows the covariance is \(29700.15\)
Running cor(random_vars) shows the correlation is \(0.548\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
4 Problem 4
Correlation is easier to interpret, because it is scaled from -1 to 1. Thus it is easily comparable between different sets of variables. However the scale of the covariance depends of the scale of the variables themselves.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
5 Problem 5



children = filter(random_vars, age<=18)
colSums(children[2]) / nrow(children)
yields \(E[\text{income}|\text{age} \le 18] = 389.61\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
2 

It does not make sense to compare the standard deviations alone, since the numbers are different orders of magnitude. That is, a difference in age by 50 is a significant, but a difference in income by 50 is not. One could scale the standard deviation in some way with respect to the expected value for a better comparison.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
3 


Running cov(random_vars) shows the covariance is \(29700.15\)
Running cor(random_vars) shows the correlation is \(0.548\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
4 

Correlation is easier to interpret, because it is scaled from -1 to 1. Thus it is easily comparable between different sets of variables. However the scale of the covariance depends of the scale of the variables themselves.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
5 


Run the following code

children = filter(random_vars, age<=18)
colSums(children[2]) / nrow(children)
to obtain \(E[\text{income}|\text{age} \le 18] = 389.61\)

Run

middle_age = filter(random_vars, age >= 18 & age < 65)
colSums(middle_age[2]) / nrow(middle_age)
to obtain \(E[\text{income}|\text{age} \in [18,65)] = 4685.73\)

Run

old = filter(random_vars, age >= 65)
colSums(old[2]) / nrow(old)
to obtain \(E[\text{income}|\text{age} \ge 65] = 1777.24\)
